default.title: Website wasn't found in Roskomnadzor's register of banned websites
default.title_negative: Website was found in Roskomnadzor's register of banned websites
default.description: Roskomnadzor blocks websites containing information banned in the Russian Federation.
default.resolve: Contact Roskomnadzor to explain the reasons for the ban. Remove or edit the content that caused the ban, and then contact Roskomnadzor so that they remove the website from the registry. You can also create a mirror site while the ban is on and redirect to it. Contact Roskomnadzor →

default.title: No fatal problems in Yandex.Webmaster
default.description: Fatal — a category of problems when the website is diagnosed by Yandex.Webmaster. Because of them the website or its URLs can be excluded from Yandex search results.
default.resolve:
Check the website for fatal problems: the main page returns an error; failed to connect to the server due to DNS error;
		the website is closed for indexing in robots.txt; violations or security problems have been detected. Fix the errors according to Yandex's instructions and wait for Webmaster to recheck the website.

default.title: robots.txt found
default.description:
robots.txt tells search engine crawlers which pages they can access. If there are errors in robots.txt, crawlers will never know
		which URLs to handle, and the website may be removed from index.
default.resolve: Check the location of the robot.txt — it should live at the root of the website (e.g., https://www.example.com/robots.txt). Check the file's HTTP status code. You need code 200 — it means the file is available. We also highly recommend to read Yandex and Google official guides on robots.txt.

default.title: sitemap.xml found
default.description: Sitemap.xml is a file with links to website's pages and resources. It tells search engines website's live structure and the relationships between URLs. If a search engine doesn't find the file, it may skip pages while indexing.

default.title: www redirect found
default.description:
Search engines consider URLs with and without www as different pages. We check redirects this way: we send requests to http://www.example.com/ and http://example.com/. If the final protocol (or redirecting URL) is the same, there will be no warning.
		Regardless of which domain is the main one — with www or viсe versa — set up the redirect, otherwise it may lead to negative impact on rankings and cause duplicate content issues.
default.resolve: Set up redirect to the version that should be the main one.

default.title: HTTP/HTTPS redirect found
default.description: Search engines consider URLs with HTTP and HTTPS as different pages. We check redirects this way: we send requests to http://example.com/ and https://example.com/. If the final protocol (or redirecting URL) is the same, there will be no warning. Also HTTPS protocol supports secure encryption. Google considers HTTPS a ranking factor, so it's strictly recommended to do use HTTPS.
default.resolve: Set up redirect from HTTP to HTTPS.

default.title: SSL/TLS certificates are up to date
default.description:
TLS and SSL certificates provide secure data transfer, so users on the website won't be notified the connection is insecure.
		SSLv2, SSLv3, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 certificates are outdated and insecure.
default.resolve:
Check the certificate's current version (it should be TLS 1.3). Add the certificate version update to the server's configuration file.
		This may require updating the server and OpenSSL library.

default.title: Successful status code (200)
default.description:
When you follow a link, server sends HTTP code to the browser indicating whether a request has been completed. Code 200 indicates the request has been successfully completed and a user opened website without problems.
		If a browser gets any other status code, users will be redirected or the page won't open.
default.resolve: Check if the URL you entered is correct.

default.title: No redirect
default.description:
Each redirect is an additional browser HTTP request. It increases pages' loadtime and negatively affects rankings. Search engines would rather
		rank higher acceptor URL (the one the redirect points to) than donor URL (the one with redirect). A redirect itself is not an error and they are often set up deliberately.
		However, as a rule you don't need to analyze pages with redirects — analyze actual pages, i.e. the ones redirects point to.
default.resolve: Replace the link with the URL the redirect points to.

default.title: No redirect chains
default.description: Redirect chain occurs when there's more than 3 URLs in redirection series. Many redirects would take a long time to load, and users may not wait for a destination acceptor URL to open.
default.resolve: Replace the link with the last URL in the redirect chain.

default.title: URLs not too long
default.description: Short URL with understandable words is easier to remember, to copy, it has higher click-through rate (CTR) and, therefore, higher rankings. We consider URL too long if it has more than 80 characters.
default.resolve: Make human-readable short SEO friendly URLs: use understandable words which correlate with page's content and are easily remembered.

default.title: Browser caching
default.description:
When browser loads a page for the first time, it saves it in the cache, so that it can open it faster next time. If there is no browser caching, a page would be loaded again from scratch each time, which can negatively affect user experience.
		To identify whether there is browser caching or not, we use a complex check that takes into account all cache-related headers. 
		There are three main reasons why the check can fail: no-store directive in Cache-Control header, past time in Expires header or server doesn't respond with 304 status code.
default.resolve: Check HTTP headers that form caching on the server.

default.title: No mixed content (https to http)
default.description: Mixed content occurs when a URL is loaded by secure HTTPS protocol, but some its links or resources (images, scripts, etc.) — by insecure HTTP. Search engines can process HTTP-resources differently, and browsers may block such resources or display warning the connection is insecure.
default.resolve: Make sure all resources on the page are loaded by secure HTTPS protocol. Perhaps, you're using external libraries that load by HTTP.

default.title: Allowed by robots.txt
default.description:
robots.txt tells search engines which URLs they can access and index while crawling the website.
		If URL is blocked by robots.txt, it most likely won't rank but it still can index in SERP if there are any links to it from another pages.
		If you don't want pages to index it's better to use noindex directive instead of blocking them by robots.txt.
default.resolve: Check disallows in robots.txt; they block search engines from accessing the page.

default.title: URLs are in sitemap.xml
default.description:
sitemap.xml contains website's URLs and tells search engines its current structure. If there's no link to a URL in sitemap.xml, search engines might skip and don't index it.
		It may not be an error if pages are irrelevant, for example if they have 3XX status code. Such pages shouldn't be in sitemap.xml and analyzed. You can delete them in Tool Settings.
default.resolve: Check if there's the URL you need in sitemap.xml and add it.

default.title: URLs in sitemap.xml are canonical
default.description:
Search engines group URLs with the same canonical together and show in SERP most relevant one.
		If there's no canonical or it's the same as the page address, the URL will be considered canonical.
		The check fails if the URL is in sitemap.xml and has another URL in link rel="canonical".
default.resolve: Only canonical pages should be in sitemap.xml. If URL is a duplicate, remove it from sitemap.xml.

default.title: No blocked URLs in sitemap.xml
default.description: sitemap.xml and robots.txt should be reconciled: pages blocked in robots.txt must be removed from sitemap.xml or unblocked.
default.resolve: Check if URL is blocked in robots.txt. If necessary, remove the URL from sitemap.xml or unblock it.

default.title: Not blocked by meta tag robots noindex/none or X-Robots-Tag: noindex/none
default.title_negative: Blocked by meta tag robots noindex/none or X-Robots-Tag: noindex/none
default.description:
Some pages such as sorting, filters, pagination should be blocked from indexing, as well as service pages, duplicates and pages under construction.
		You can do this by using noindex/none meta tags and X-Robots-Tag: noindex/none headers.
		If the page is blocked from indexing, it doesn't need a detailed analysis so you can delete it from future checks in Tool Setting.
default.resolve: Check meta tags and page headers; if pages need to be ranked, replace them with index/all. Also check official guides on how to block indexing from Yandex and Google.

default.title: Links are not blocked by meta tag robots nofollow or X-Robots-Tag: nofollow
default.title_negative: Links are blocked by meta tag robots nofollow or X-Robots-Tag: nofollow
default.description:
nofollow blocks links on pages for search engine crawlers. They don't follow such links and acceptor website don't get link weight.
		Even if a crawler does follow a link, nofollow will show the acceptor website isn't thrustworthy.
		Search engines can find these links on other pages and websites, but nofollow will negatively affect its rankings.
default.resolve: Check meta tags and page headers; if you want crawlers to index the links, remove nofollow. Also check official guides on how to block link indexing from Yandex and Google.

default.title: URLs have canonical
default.description:
Search engines may consider pages with the same content without canonical URL as duplicates and penalize them. If there are canonicals, search engine will group pages together and rank most relevant one.
		We consider that a page has canonical if it has no canonical (it's canonical to oiself) or there's a URL in link rel="canonical". Check fails if there're duplicates (URLs with tha same Title or Description) which canonicals are absent or different. In that case search engine can incorrectly define which URL it should rank.
default.resolve: Add rel="canonical" to necessary URLs and specify canonical URL. Also check official guides on canonicals from Yandex and Google.

default.title: Valid alternates
default.description:
alternate tag helps search engines to identify the same pages in different languages for different locations.
		We consider alternate valid if it has href attribute and one of attributes hreflang, type or media.
default.resolve: Fix invalid alternate by specifying href attribute and one of attributes hreflang, type or media. Also check official guides on working with localized versions of the page from Yandex and Google.

default.title: URLs have outbound links
default.description: Outbound links help search engines find other pages on the website. If there's no links on the page, it's a dead end: crawlers and users will have no choice but to leave the website.
default.resolve: Add links to other website pages such as header, footer, breadcrumbs or recommended pages.

default.title: No meta refresh redirect
default.description:
Meta refresh redirect tag means the user will be redirected to another page after some time.
		W3C doesn't recommend to use refresh redirect as you can't know how much time a user would need to read the text on the page. Also some browsers don't support refresh tag.
default.resolve: Replace the refresh redirect tag with 301 redirect.

default.title: Title found
default.description:
Title tag is displayed as a title in search results. It also appears in the browser tab and elsewhere. It contains key information about the page content;
		search engines determine its relevance by the title.
default.resolve: Check if there is a title tag in the page source code and fill it in — if there's a tag but it's empty, the check will be failed. Avoid generalities and unnecessary non-informative words.

default.title: No Title duplicates
default.description: If Title is duplicated, it will be more difficult for search engines to determine which page is the the most relevant one. It may consider one of the pages a duplicate and drop it from SERP.
default.resolve: Check which URLs have duplicating Titles and rewrite them to make each Title unique. To see such URLs, click on the number in the column URL, and then on the number in the column Duplicates / Title.

default.title: Title not too long
default.description: We consider title tag long if it has more than 80 characters. Search engines would cut off such long Titles in SERP. Cropped Title negatively affects CTR.
default.resolve: See which URLs have long Title and rewrite it so that it can stay within 80 characters.

default.title: Description found
default.description:
Search engines use Description metatag to describe a page in the search results. Description may end up in the snippet, but search engine can grab something from page content,
		if it considers description to convey the content poorly. Description affects URLs' CTR in SERP.
default.resolve: Check if there is a description tag in the page source code and fill it in — if there's a tag but it's empty, the check will be failed. Focus on text relevance and avoid keyword stuffing (spamming).

default.title: No Description duplicates
default.description: If the text in Description tag isn't unique, search engines won't grab it for a snippet in search results. It may affect page relevance and its rankings. To see URLs with description duplicates click on the number in the column URL, and then on the number in the column Duplicates / Description.
default.resolve: Check which URLs have duplicating Descriptions and rewrite them to make each description unique.

default.title: Description not too short
default.description: Description should stay within 150-250 characters. If a description is shorter, search engines may consider it uninformative and replace with something from the page content.
default.resolve: See URLs with short Descriptions and rewrite them so that all Descriptions have at least 150 characters.

default.title: Description not too long
default.description: Description should stay within 150-250 characters. Description which doesn't exceed 250 characters won't be cut in search results. Cropped Description negatively affects user experience.
default.resolve: See URLs with long Descriptions and rewrite them so that they meet the 250 characters limit.

default.title: H1 found
default.description: H1–H6 headings are used to represent page structure. H1 is the main heading indicating the topic of all page content; it helps search engines to determine page relevance.
default.resolve: Check if there is a H1 heading in the page source code and fill it in — if there's a heading but it's empty, the check will be failed. Look up to text relevance, don't use Title as H1.

default.title: lang found
default.description: lang attribute contains page language. lang helps browsers correctly display characters which differ in different languages (i. o. quotes).
default.resolve: Check if there is lang attribute in the page source code and fill it in. If there's text on different languages on a page, you can indicate lang for each language.

default.title: Good FCP (First Contentful Paint)
default.description:
FCP (First Contentful Paint) is the time from when a user starts loading the page to when any part of the page's content appears on the screen.
		FCP should be <1600 ms for desktop and <3000 ms for mobile devices.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: To improve FCP, work on page loadtime: check TTFB, don't use lazy loading for recources above the fold, avoid redirects. More on FCP in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good SI (Speed Index)
default.description:
SI (Speed Index) is the time a page need for content to be visually displayed.
		SI should be <2300 ms for desktop and <5800 ms for mobile devices.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Make content appear faster: minify JS и CSS files, optimize images, defer loading of rarely used scripts.

default.title: Good LCP (Largest Contentful Paint)
default.description:
LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) is the render time of the largest image or text block visible within the viewport.
		LCP should be <2,5 s after loading starts.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Compress heavy content (i.g., images) or add lazy loading in URLs HTML code. If that doesn't work, pay attention to TTFB and check if JavaScript and CSS rendering is blocked. More on LCP in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good TBT (Total Blocking Time)
default.description:
TBT (Total Blocking Time) is the time a page can't respond to user input (mouse clicking, screen tapping or keyboard pressing). 
		TBT should be <350 ms for desktop and <600 ms for mobile devices.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Defer execution of unnecessary JavaScript code, minify JS-files. More on TBT in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift)
default.description:
CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift) is the largest burst of the unexpected layout shift.
		CLS should be <0,1% of shifting.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Check if the page is correctly adapted for different devices and animation settings. Add size attributes for images and videos if necessary. More on CLS in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good FID (First Input Delay)
default.description:
FID (First Input Delay) is the time a server responds after the first user interaction (i.g., pressing a button or following a link).
		FID should be <100 ms.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Check JavaScript execution time and try to reduce it. Break code snippets running >50 ms into smaller tasks. Postpone unused JavaScript by using async or defer tags. More on FID in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good INP (Interaction to Next Paint)
default.description:
INP (Interaction to Next Paint) is a metric that assesses page responsiveness on user actions (clicks, taps, keyboard interactions). Good INP means that the page quickly responses on such actions as opening sidemenu or adding an item to a cart. INP should be <200 ms.
		We check for the metric only if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, there won't be any data on Core Web Vitals.
default.resolve: Check JavaScript execution time and try to reduce it. Check if styles are more complicated than necessary. More on INP in developers' guidelines →

default.title: Good TTFB (Time to First Byte)
default.description:
TTFB (Time To First Byte) is the time from when a browser sends a request to when the first byte of a response from the server arrives. TTFB should be <500 ms.
		Long server response time negatively affects page rankings and user experience.
default.resolve: TTFB depends on many factors such as website caching, database optimization and server performance. To improve TTFB check technical performance of the website.

default.title: og:title found
default.description:
Open Graph is a meta tag markup that allows to create an attractive preview of a page when publishing a link on social media.
		Meta tag og:title stands for a header and Title tag.
default.resolve: Check the page HTML-code and add og:title meta tag. Don't make og:title too long — headers on socials are much shorter than in search. More on Open Graph in the official Yandex guide →

default.title: og:description found
default.description:
Open Graph is a meta tag markup that allows to create an attractive preview of a page when publishing a link on social media.
		Meta tag og:description contains a brief description of the page content and stands for Description tag.
default.resolve: Check the page HTML-code and add og:description. Don't make og:description too long — headers on socials are much shorter than in search. More on Open Graph in the official Yandex guide →

default.title: og:image found
default.description:
Open Graph is a meta tag markup that allows to create an attractive preview of a page when publishing a link on social media.
		og:image meta tag contains the image that will be displayed in the page preview.
default.resolve: Check the page HTML-code and add og:image. Specify the image URL in the meta tag. Image size should be >1200x630 px and weigh <5 Mb — such image will look good in most social networks. More on Open Graph in the official Yandex guide →

default.title: og:url found
default.description:
Open Graph is a meta tag markup that allows to create an attractive preview of a page when publishing a link on social media.
		og:url meta tag contains the canonical URL where user will land after clicking the preview.
default.resolve: Check the page HTML-code and add og:url. In the meta tag there should be the target URL a user should land on after following the link in preview. More on Open Graph in the official Yandex guide →

default.title: og:url matches canonical
default.description:
Canonical URL helps search engines to identify target URL among similar URLs.
		In Open Graph markup og:url should match canonical so that if users click a preview link they will land on a target URL.
default.resolve: Check og:url meta tag and add a canonical URL in it. More on Open Graph in the official Yandex guide →

default.title: Successful status code (200)
default.description:
When user follows a link, server sends HTTP code to the browser indicating whether a request has been completed.
		Code 200 indicates the request has been successfully completed and a user followed a link without problems. If a browser gets any other status code, users will be redirected or a link won't open.
default.resolve: Check if the link URL is correct.

default.title: No redirect
default.description: Each redirect is an additional browser HTTP request. It increases pages' loadtime and negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the page to load.
default.resolve: Replace the link with the URL the redirect points to.

default.title: No redirect chains
default.description: Redirect chain occurs when there's more than 3 URLs in redirection series. Many redirects would take a long time to load, and users may not wait for a destination acceptor URL to open.
default.resolve: Replace the link with the last URL in the redirect chain.

default.title: Good TTFB (Time to First Byte)
default.description: TTFB (Time To First Byte) is the time from when a browser sends a request to when the first byte of a response from the server arrives. TTFB should be <500 ms. Long server response time negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the page to open.
default.resolve: TTFB depends on many factors such as website caching, database optimization and server performance. To improve TTFB check technical performance of the website.

default.title: No double slashes in URL
default.description: Even if a user successfully opens a page with double slashes, it may be misleading for search engines. Pages with one slash and two slashes will be considered two different but similar pages. Example of the wrong URL: https://site.com//
default.resolve: Remove the duplicate slash from links URL.

default.title: No capital letters or spaces in URL
default.title_negative: Capital letters or spaces in URL
default.description:
It's better to make URLs for users to remember easier, so there shouldn't be capital letters in URLs. As for spaces, they can't be contained in URLs and will be replaced by a + or %20, making URLs harder for users to read.
		Also, the percent symbol, as well as ampersand, dollar and other symbols can prevent the correct indexing of the page.
default.resolve: Remove capital letters and spaces from links URLs. Don't forget to set up redirects from the old to new URLs.

default.title: Text anchors found
default.title_negative: Text anchors or titles not found
default.description:
Anchor is the visible text of a link. Search engines analyze anchors and use them to determine the page relevance.
		For example, if links have too many anchors with commercial intent keywords, it will negatively affect rankings. And if there's no anchor at all, search engines won't take it into account. If there's the same link with different anchors on a page, they all would be displayed in the table.
default.resolve: Add anchor text inside the link tag or title attribute.

default.title: Crawlers are allowed to follow links (no nofollow)
default.title_negative: Crawlers are not allowed to follow links (nofollow found)
default.description:
nofollow attribute doesn't allow search crawlers to follow links, and they won't give link weight to a website.
		Even if a crawler does follow a link, nofollow will show the acceptor website isn't thrustworthy.
		Search engines can find these links on other pages and websites, but nofollow will negatively affect its rankings.
default.resolve: If you want crawlers to index the links, remove nofollow. Also check official guides on how to block link indexing from Yandex and Google.

default.title: Successful status code (200)
default.description:
When a browser loads an image on the page, server sends HTTP code indicating whether a request has been completed.
		Code 200 indicates the request has been successfully completed — an image is displayed. If a browser gets any other status code, an image won't open.
default.resolve: Check if the image URL is correct.

default.title: No redirect
default.description: Each redirect is an additional browser HTTP request. It increases pages' loadtime and negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the image to load.
default.resolve: Replace the link to the image with the URL the redirect points to.

default.title: No redirect chains
default.description: Redirect chain occurs when there's more than 3 URLs in redirection series. Many redirects would take a long time to load, and it would negatively affects user experience — while destination image would be in the process of loading, the image could be displayed incorrectly, and users would leave the page.
default.resolve: Replace the link to the image with the last URL in the redirect chain.

default.title: Good TTFB (Time to First Byte)
default.description: TTFB (Time To First Byte) is the time from when a browser sends a request to when the first byte of a response from the server arrives. TTFB should be <500 ms. Long server response time negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the image to open and leave the page.
default.resolve: TTFB depends on many factors such as website caching, database optimization and server performance. To improve TTFB check technical performance of the website.

default.title: Browser caching
default.description:
When browser loads a page for the first time, it saves it in the cache, so that it can open it faster next time. If there is no browser caching, a page and its resources would be loaded again from scratch each time, which can negatively affect user experience.
		To identify whether resources on the page have browser caching or not, we use a complex check that takes into account all cache-related headers.
		There are three main reasons why the check can fail: no-store directive in Cache-Control header, past time in Expires header or server doesn't respond with 304 status code.
default.resolve: Check HTTP headers that form caching on the server.

default.title: alt text found
default.description: If an image didn't load, user would see alt text instead. Also, search engines use this text for image search ranging.
default.resolve: Check if there's text in alt attribute of img tag.

default.title: alt text not too long
default.description: Search engines can ignore alt text if it is too long. There shouldn't be too many commercial intent keywords: crawlers may consider it keyword stuffing.
default.resolve: Make alt text shorter so that there's only the gist of what is pictured on the image.

default.title: Images not too big
default.description: The less is images weight, the faster they will load and the faster will load the page as a whole, especially on mobile devices. Images should be <500 Kb for .gif and <100 Kb for other formats.
default.resolve: Reduce images weight — you can compress them in special converters.

default.title: Allowed by robots.txt
default.description:
robots.txt tells search engines which URLs they can access and index while crawling the website.
		If an image is blocked by robots.txt, it most likely won't rank.
default.resolve: Check disallows in robots.txt; they block search engines from accessing the image.

default.title: Modern image format
default.description: We consider outdated formats JPEG and PNG. New formats JPEG 2000, JPEG XR and WebP show much better quality and compressing performance comparing with their old counterparts.
default.resolve: Replace images with outdated formats with new ones.

default.title: Successful status code (200)
default.description:
When a browser loads page resources, server sends HTTP code indicating whether a request has been completed.
		Code 200 indicates the request has been successfully completed. If a browser gets any other status code, resources won't be loaded.
default.resolve: Check if the resource URL is correct.

default.title: No redirect
default.description: Each redirect is an additional browser HTTP request. It increases pages' loadtime and negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for resources to load.
default.resolve: Replace the link to resources with the URL the redirect points to.

default.title: No redirect chains
default.description: Redirect chain occurs when there's more than 3 URLs in redirection series. Many redirects would take a long time to load, and it would negatively affects user experience — while destination resource would be in the process of loading, page content could be displayed incorrectly, and users would leave the page.
default.resolve: Replace the link to resources with the last URL in the redirect chain.

default.title: Good TTFB (Time to First Byte)
default.description: TTFB (Time To First Byte) is the time from when a browser sends a request to when the first byte of a response from the server arrives. TTFB should be <500 ms. Long server response time negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the page to open correctly while resources are loading and leave the page.
default.resolve: TTFB depends on many factors such as website caching, database optimization and server performance. To improve TTFB check technical performance of the website.

default.title: Browser caching
default.description:
When browser loads a page for the first time, it saves it in the cache, so that it can open it faster next time. If there is no browser caching, a page and its resources would be loaded again from scratch each time, which can negatively affect user experience.
		To identify whether resources on the page have browser caching or not, we use a complex check that takes into account all cache-related headers.
		There are three main reasons why the check can fail: no-store directive in Cache-Control header, past time in Expires header or server doesn't respond with 304 status code.
default.resolve: Check HTTP headers that form caching on the server.

default.title: Minified
default.description:
Minification allows you to reduce file size by removing unnecessary characters: spaces, comments, indentation, etc. This reduces code size and speeds up loading without affecting functionality.
		If you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings, we'll take results from there. If there's no key, we'll try to minify files ourselves and compare results by weight.
default.resolve: Minify files. This can be done manually or by automatic minifiers.

default.title: Doesn't block rendering
default.description:
Rendering is the process of converting JavaScript code into HTML readable by search engines. Unlike ordinary ones, SPA-websites look like JS-files which contains HTML-code instead of looking like HTML markup alone.
		After requesting JS-files, HTML markup in browser is formed which a search engine can "read". If files don't be rendered, search engines won't see page content.
		We check render blocking if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, we don't check rendering.
default.resolve: Check what can block file rendering. Use minification and encoding to reduce file size.

default.title: Successful status code (200)
default.description:
When a browser loads page resources, server sends HTTP code indicating whether a request has been completed.
		Code 200 indicates the request has been successfully completed. If a browser gets any other status code, resources won't be loaded.
default.resolve: Check if the resource URL is correct.

default.title: No redirect
default.description: Each redirect is an additional browser HTTP request. It increases pages' loadtime and negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for resources to load.
default.resolve: Replace the link to resources with the URL the redirect points to.

default.title: No redirect chains
default.description: Redirect chain occurs when there's more than 3 URLs in redirection series. Many redirects would take a long time to load, and it would negatively affects user experience — while destination resource would be in the process of loading, page content could be displayed incorrectly, and users would leave the page.
default.resolve: Replace the link to resources with the last URL in the redirect chain.

default.title: Good TTFB (Time to First Byte)
default.description: TTFB (Time To First Byte) is the time from when a browser sends a request to when the first byte of a response from the server arrives. TTFB should be <500 ms. Long server response time negatively affects user experience — they may not wait for the page to open correctly while resources are loading and leave the page.
default.resolve: TTFB depends on many factors such as website caching, database optimization and server performance. To improve TTFB check technical performance of the website.

default.title: Browser caching
default.description:
When browser loads a page for the first time, it saves it in the cache, so that it can open it faster next time. If there is no browser caching, a page and its resources would be loaded again from scratch each time, which can negatively affect user experience.
		To identify whether resources on the page have browser caching or not, we use a complex check that takes into account all cache-related headers.
		There are three main reasons why the check can fail: no-store directive in Cache-Control header, past time in Expires header or server doesn't respond with 304 status code.
default.resolve: Check HTTP headers that form caching on the server.

default.title: Minified
default.description:
Minification allows you to reduce file size by removing unnecessary characters: spaces, comments, indentation, etc. This reduces code size and speeds up loading without affecting functionality.
		If you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings, we'll take results from there. If there's no key, we'll try to minify files ourselves and compare results by weight.
default.resolve: Minify files. This can be done manually or by automatic minifiers.

default.title: Doesn't block rendering
default.description:
Rendering is the process of converting JavaScript code into HTML readable by search engines. Unlike ordinary ones, SPA-websites look like JS-files which contains HTML-code instead of looking like HTML markup alone.
		After requesting JS-files, HTML markup in browser is formed which a search engine can "read". If files don't be rendered, search engines won't see page content.
		We check render blocking if you've added PageSpeed Insights API-key in Tool Settings. If there's no key, we don't check rendering.
default.resolve: Check what can block file rendering. Use minification and encoding to reduce file size.
